spanishExample: ¡Qué lo pasen bien!
englishTranslation: May you(plural) have a good time!
vocabIncluded: "que" at the beginning of a phrase to mean "may"
pasarlo bien: "to have a good time" (idiom)
pasen: pass, they pass (Pasar, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Setenta y seis personas en este lugar es un peligro.
englishTranslation: Seventy-six people in this place is a hazard.

spanishExample: Él contó sesenta y uno, pero nosotros contamos sesenta y siete.
englishTranslation: He counted sixty-one, but we counted sixty-seven.
vocabIncluded: contamos: counted/told, we counted/told (Contar, preterite, 1st person plural)
contó: counted/told, he/she/it counted/told (Contar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Cuéntanos qué pasó con el sistema.
englishTranslation: Tell us what happened with the system.
vocabIncluded: "qué" in an implied question, not an actual question
cuéntanos: tell to us (Contar, imperative contraction)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No tienes que contarme nada de los años setenta.
englishTranslation: You don’t have to tell me anything about the seventies.
vocabIncluded: contarme: to tell me (Contar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No cuentes hasta el número setenta y siete, cuenta hasta el setenta y ocho.
englishTranslation: Don’t count to the number seventy-seven, count to seventy-eight.

spanishExample: Cuéntale lo que pasó con el servicio.
englishTranslation: Tell him what happened with the service.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
cuéntale: tell to him/her (Contar, imperative contraction)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Cuentas mejor si tienes calma.
englishTranslation: You count better if you have calm.
vocabIncluded: cuentas: count/tell, you count/tell (Contar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Todavía está contando y hay setenta y un dólares hasta ahora.
englishTranslation: He’s still counting and there are seventy-one dollars until now.
vocabIncluded: hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Tienes que contarle el modo en el que lo hicimos.
englishTranslation: You have to tell her the mode in which we did it.
vocabIncluded: "el que" to mean "which" after a preposition
contarle: to tell him/her (Contar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Esto vale setenta y tres dólares y esos valen setenta y cinco.
englishTranslation: This is worth seventy-three dollars and those are worth seventy-five.
vocabIncluded: vale: is worth, he/she/it is worth (Valer, present, 3rd person)
valen: are worth, they are worth (Valer, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: La ley dice que tengo derechos.
englishTranslation: The law says that I have rights.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Ella quiere que yo cuente con su fuerza.
englishTranslation: She wants me to count on her strength.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cuente: count/tell, I count/tell (Contar, subjunctive, 1st person)

spanishExample: Mi libertad valió la pena.
englishTranslation: My freedom was worth it.
vocabIncluded: valer la pena: to be worth it (idiom)
valió: was worth, he/she/it was worth (Valer, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Te contaré toda la historia, pero primero tenemos que estar en silencio.
englishTranslation: I will tell you the whole story, but first we need to be in silence.
vocabIncluded: contaré: will count/tell, I will count/tell (Contar, future, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: ¿Viste la nueva ley sobre servicios?
englishTranslation: Did you see the new law about services?
vocabIncluded: viste: saw, you saw (Ver, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Quiero que cuentes setenta y una cosas.
englishTranslation: I want you to count seventy-one things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cuentes: count/tell, you count/tell (Contar, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Cuénteme lo que pasó en el programa.
englishTranslation: (Formal) Tell me what happened in the program.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
cuénteme: tell me (Contar formal imperative contraction)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Qué tengas un buen día en el trabajo!
englishTranslation: May you have a good day at work!
vocabIncluded: "que" at the beginning of a phrase to mean "may"

spanishExample: Esto valía más el año pasado.
englishTranslation: This was worth more last year.
vocabIncluded: valía: was worth, he/she/it was worth (Valer, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No me contaste toda la historia, entonces cuéntala ahora.
englishTranslation: You didn’t tell me the whole story, so tell it now.
vocabIncluded: contaste: counted/told, you counted/told (Contar, preterite, 2nd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Vales lo mismo que nosotros valemos.
englishTranslation: You are worth the same as we are worth.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
valemos: are worth, we are worth (Valer, present, 1st person plural)
vales: are worth, you are worth (Valer, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Cuéntalos y dime si hay sesenta y dos o sesenta y nueve.
englishTranslation: Count them and tell me if there are sixty-two or sixty-nine.
vocabIncluded: "o": "or" when used between items in a list
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Ella sabe que cuenta conmigo y nosotros contamos con ella.
englishTranslation: She knows she counts on me and we count on her.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
contamos: count/tell, we count/tell (Contar, present, 1st person plural)
cuenta: counts/tells, he/she/it counts/tells (Contar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quería contarte todo, pero necesitamos estar en silencio.
englishTranslation: I wanted to tell you everything, but we need to be in silence.
vocabIncluded: contarte: to tell you (Contar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
necesitamos: need, we need (Necesitar, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Valgo mucho, así que debería estar en el programa.
englishTranslation: I’m worth a lot, so I should be in the program.
vocabIncluded: valgo: am worth, I am worth (Valer, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: No creo que la libertad no valga nada.
englishTranslation: I don’t think freedom isn’t worth anything.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
valga: be worth, he/she/it be worth (Valer, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Había como sesenta y seis personas ahí, yo las conté.
englishTranslation: There were around sixty-six people there, I counted them.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
conté: counted/told, I counted/told (Contar, preterite, 1st person)
había: "there was/were" indicating existence (Haber, imperfect, impersonal)
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things

spanishExample: Quiero que ella me cuente sobre los años sesenta.
englishTranslation: I want her to tell me about the sixties.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cuente: count/tell, he/she/it count/tell (Contar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: El sistema solo sabe contar hasta setenta y cuatro.
englishTranslation: The system only knows how to count until seventy-four.

spanishExample: Tengo derecho a no sentirme en peligro.
englishTranslation: I have a right not to feel in danger.
vocabIncluded: a: complement (e.g. ayudar a, empezar a) (preposition)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)

spanishExample: Si lo haces de este modo, necesitarás más fuerza.
englishTranslation: If you do it in this mode, you’ll need more force.

spanishExample: No te he contado lo que pasó aún, ten calma.
englishTranslation: I haven’t told you what happened yet, have calm.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
he: "have", "I have" before a participle (Haber, present, 1st person)
pasó: passed, he/she/it passed (Pasar, preterite, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Valieron como diez dólares.
englishTranslation: They were worth about ten dollars.
vocabIncluded: valieron: were worth, they were worth (Valer, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Vale, yo cuento con ellos y ellos cuentan conmigo.
englishTranslation: Sure, I count on them and they count on me.
vocabIncluded: cuentan: count/tell, they count/tell (Contar, present, 3rd person plural)
cuento: count/tell, I count/tell (Contar, present, 1st person)
